"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Congress finds a crisis in writing skills in schools and workplaces, with nearly 1/3 of high school graduates not ready for college-level English composition. Deficiencies in writing skills cost the private sector billions annually. Writing is crucial for employment and promotion, and is a key feature in educational standards. The annual private-sector costs for providing writing training are as high as $3.1 billion. Writing is a central feature in State and local educational standards. The National Writing Project is the only national program addressing the writing problem in schools since 1973, showing significant gains in student performance and effective classroom practices. The National Writing Project has shown significant gains in student performance and effective classroom practices. It serves as a model for programs in various fields and benefits over 135,000 teachers annually in nearly 200 sites across the US. The National Writing Project, a successful program benefiting teachers across the US, is reauthorized under Subpart 2 of part C of title II of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The purposes of this subpart are to support and expand the National Writing Project network, ensure high quality sites, disseminate effective practices, and coordinate activities under this Act. "SEC. 2332. NATIONAL WRITING PROJECT." The Secretary is authorized to award a grant to the National Writing Project, a nonprofit organization focused on improving student writing and learning. The grant aims to enhance writing teaching and learning in classrooms by partnering with educational providers. The grantee will contract with educational providers to establish teacher training programs for writing. Funds from the Secretary will cover the Federal share of program costs. The grantee will use funds from the Secretary to establish and operate teacher training programs, meeting conditions set by the Secretary for compliance. Teacher training programs authorized in subsection (a) will be implemented. Teacher training programs authorized in subsection (a) will provide technical assistance and train teachers from kindergarten to college. Selected teachers will join a National Writing Project teacher network to conduct workshops for other teachers. The Federal Share for teacher training programs authorized in subsection (a) is 50% of the costs to the contractor. The Secretary may waive this requirement on a case-by-case basis based on financial need as determined by the National Advisory Board. The Federal share for teacher training programs is limited to $150,000 for any one contractor or $300,000 for a statewide program. The National Writing Project will establish a National Advisory Board consisting of national educational leaders. The National Writing Project will establish a National Advisory Board composed of national educational leaders, leaders in the field of writing, and other necessary individuals. The Board will advise on national issues related to student writing and the teaching of writing. The National Advisory Board established by the National Writing Project will advise on student writing issues, review programs, and support project development. The Secretary will conduct an independent evaluation of teacher training programs. The Secretary will conduct an independent evaluation of teacher training programs administered by the National Writing Project, specifying funds expended and making results available to Congress. The Secretary will reserve funds for the evaluation of teacher training programs by the National Writing Project. A National Review Board will be established consisting of leaders in writing research. The National Writing Project will establish a National Review Board comprised of leaders in writing research to review and recommend applications for funding. The National Writing Project will establish a National Review Board to review and recommend applications for funding under this subsection. $30,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008, with additional funding for the following 5 years.
